math 24.description: Directed study projects as arranged with a faculty member.

math 25.name: INTRODUCTION TO PROBABILITY AND MATHEMATICAL STATISTICS I
math 25.subject: Mathematics
math 25.description: Probability and combinatorial methods, discrete and continuous, univariate and multivariate distributions, expected values, moments, normal distribution and derived distributions, estimation.
math 25.requisite: Requisites: MATH234, 376, or concurrent enrollment. Not open to students with credit for STAT/MATH431 or STAT311

math 26.name: INTRODUCTION TO PROBABILITY AND MATHEMATICAL STATISTICS II
math 26.subject: Mathematics
math 26.description: Mathematical statistical inference aims at providing an understanding of likelihood's central role to statistical inference, using the language of mathematical statistics to analyze statistical procedures, and using the computer as a tool for understanding statistics. Specific topics include: samples and populations, estimation, hypothesis testing, and theoretical properties of statistical inference.
math 26.requisite: Requisites: (STAT/MATH309, STAT311, STAT/MATH431, or MATH531) and (STAT240, STAT301, STAT302, STAT324, STAT371, or ECON310), or graduate/professional standing

math 27.name: TECHNIQUES IN ORDINARY DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS
math 27.subject: Mathematics
math 27.description: Review of linear differential equations; series solution of linear differential equations; boundary value problems; Laplace transforms; possibly numerical methods and two dimensional autonomous systems.

math 28.name: LINEAR ALGEBRA AND DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS
math 28.subject: Mathematics
math 28.description: An introduction to linear algebra and differential equations with emphasis on the relationship between the theory of linear algebra and analytical and numerical techniques for solving differential equations. Linear algebra topics include linear systems, matrices and their algebra, vector spaces and linear transformations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Topics from differential equations include first order ODE, homogeneous and nonhomogeneous linear systems, and numerical methods.

math 29.name: APPLIED MATHEMATICAL ANALYSIS
math 29.subject: Mathematics
math 29.description: Vector analysis: algebra and geometry of vectors, vector differential and integral calculus, theorems of Green, Gauss, and Stokes; complex analysis: analytic functions, complex integrals and residues, Taylor and Laurent series.
math 29.requisite: Requisites: MATH376, (MATH234 and 319), (MATH234 and 320), (MATH234 and 340), (MATH234 and 341), (MATH234 and 375), or graduate/professional standing

math 30.name: APPLIED MATHEMATICAL ANALYSIS
math 30.subject: Mathematics
math 30.description: Sturm-Liouville theory; Fourier series, including mean convergence; boundary value problems for linear second order partial differential equations, including separation of variables and eigenfunction expansions.
math 30.requisite: Requisites: MATH321 or 376 or graduate/professional standing

math 31.name: AN INTRODUCTION TO PROBABILITY AND MARKOV CHAIN MODELS
math 31.subject: Mathematics
math 31.description: An overview of basic probability including discrete and continuous random variables, moment generating functions, limit theorems, conditional probability and expectations, random walks, and Markov chains.

math 32.name: ELEMENTARY MATRIX AND LINEAR ALGEBRA
math 32.subject: Mathematics
math 32.description: An introduction to linear algebra. Topics include matrix algebra, linear systems of equations, vector spaces, sub-spaces, linear dependence, span, basis, rank of matrices, determinants, linear transformations, coordinate representations, kernel, range, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization, inner products and orthogonal vectors, symmetric matrices. Covers linear algebra topics in greater depth and detail than MATH320. Formal techniques in mathematical argument [MATH341] not covered.

math 33.name: LINEAR ALGEBRA
math 33.subject: Mathematics
math 33.description: The theory of linear algebra with an introduction to proofs and proof writing. Topics include vector spaces, linear dependence, span, basis, linear transformations, kernel, image, inner products and inner product spaces, geometry, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, standard matrix factorizations. Other content includes basic set theory, logical operations, quantifiers, direct and indirect arguments, and induction. Differential equations [MATH320] not covered.

math 34.name: TOPICS IN MULTI-VARIABLE CALCULUS AND LINEAR ALGEBRA
math 34.subject: Mathematics
math 34.description: Vector spaces and linear transformations, differential calculus of scalar and vector fields, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, multiple integrals, line integrals, and surface integrals. Freshmen students are invited to enroll by the Department of Mathematics.

math 35.name: TOPICS IN MULTI-VARIABLE CALCULUS AND DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS
math 35.subject: Mathematics
math 35.description: Topics in multi-variable calculus and introduction to differential equations.

math 36.name: UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH WITH MADISON EXPERIMENTAL MATHEMATICS LAB
math 36.subject: Mathematics
math 36.description: An introduction to mathematical research. Instruction in ancillary skills such as literature review, mathematical software use, technical  writing and communication, etc. Requires acceptance to the Madison Experimental Mathematics undergraduate research lab.

math 37.name: THE THEORY OF SINGLE VARIABLE CALCULUS
math 37.subject: Mathematics
math 37.description: Covers material in first and second semester calculus but it is intended to teach math majors to write and understand proofs in mathematics in general and in calculus in particular.
math 37.requisite: Requisites: MATH234 or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 38.name: INTRODUCTION TO COMBINATORIAL OPTIMIZATION
math 38.subject: Mathematics
math 38.description: Focuses on optimization problems over discrete structures, such as shortest paths, spanning trees, flows, matchings, and the traveling salesman problem. We will investigate structural properties of these problems, and we will study both exact methods for their solution, and approximation algorithms.
math 38.requisite: Requisites: (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 39.name: INTRODUCTION TO THE THEORY OF PROBABILITY
math 39.subject: Mathematics
math 39.description: Topics covered include axioms of probability, random variables, the most important discrete and continuous probability distributions, expectation and variance, moment generating functions, conditional probability and conditional expectations, multivariate distributions, Markov's and Chebyshev's inequalities, laws of large numbers, and the central limit theorem.
math 39.requisite: Requisites: MATH234 or 376 or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 40.name: INTRODUCTION TO CRYPTOGRAPHY
math 40.subject: Mathematics
math 40.description: Cryptography is the art and science of transmitting digital information in a secure manner. Provides an introduction to its technical aspects.
math 40.requisite: Requisites: (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 41.name: INTRODUCTION TO MODERN ALGEBRA
math 41.subject: Mathematics
math 41.description: The integers, emphasizing general group and ring properties. Permutation groups, symmetry groups, polynomial rings, leading to notions of abstract groups and rings. Congruences, computations, including finite fields and applications. Emphasis on concepts and concrete examples and computations.
math 41.requisite: Requisites: (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 42.name: APPLIED LINEAR ALGEBRA
math 42.subject: Mathematics
math 42.description: Review of matrix algebra. Simultaneous linear equations, linear dependence and rank, vector space, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization, quadratic forms, inner product spaces, norms, canonical forms. Discussion of numerical aspects and applications in the sciences.
math 42.requisite: Requisites: (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 43.name: COLLEGE GEOMETRY I
math 43.subject: Mathematics
math 43.description: An introduction to Euclidean or non-Euclidean geometry.
math 43.requisite: Requisites: MATH234 or (MATH222 and COMPSCI/MATH240) or MATH375 or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International)  Program

math 44.name: INTRODUCTION TO NUMBER THEORY
math 44.subject: Mathematics
math 44.description: An introduction to proof writing techniques through a study of classical topics in elementary number theory. Topics include the divisibility, basic properties of primes, congruences, Fermat's theorem.
math 44.requisite: Requisites: MATH234, 375, (222 and COMPSCI/MATH240), (222 and 320), or (222 and 340)

math 45.name: MATHEMATICS FOR SECONDARY SCHOOL TEACHERS
math 45.subject: Mathematics
math 45.description: Capstone for future middle and high school teachers, drawing connections between higher mathematics and school mathematics.
math 45.requisite: Requisites: (MATH341, 375, or 421) and (MATH461 or concurrent enrollment)

math 46.name: HISTORY OF MATHEMATICS
math 46.subject: Mathematics
math 46.description: An historical survey of the main lines of mathematical development.

math 47.name: INTRODUCTION TO COMBINATORICS
math 47.subject: Mathematics
math 47.description: Problems of enumeration, distribution, and arrangement. Inclusion-exclusion principle. Generating functions and linear recurrence relations. Combinatorial identities. Graph coloring problems. Finite designs. Systems of distinct representatives and matching problems in graphs. Potential applications in the social, biological, and physical sciences. Puzzles. Problem solving.
math 47.requisite: Requisites: (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 48.name: UNDERGRADUATE SEMINAR
math 48.subject: Mathematics
math 48.description: Intermediate or upper level topics course in mathematics. Topics vary.

math 49.name: TOPICS IN UNDERGRADUATE MATHEMATICS
math 49.subject: Mathematics
math 49.description: Intermediate or upper level topics course in mathematics. Topics vary.

math 50.name: NUMERICAL LINEAR ALGEBRA
math 50.subject: Mathematics
math 50.description: Direct and iterative solution of linear and nonlinear systems and of eigenproblems. LU and symmetric LU factorization. Complexity, stability, and conditioning. Nonlinear systems. Iterative methods for linear systems. QR-factorization and least squares. Eigenproblems: local and global methods.
math 50.requisite: Requisites: (MATH340, 341, or 375) and (COMPSCI200, 300, 301, 302 or 310) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) program

math 51.name: NUMERICAL ANALYSIS
math 51.subject: Mathematics
math 51.description: Polynomial forms, divided differences. Polynomial interpolation. Polynomial approximation: uniform approximation and Chebyshev polynomials, least-squares approximation and orthogonal polynomials. Numerical differentiation and integration. Splines, B-splines and spline approximation. Numerical methods for solving initial and boundary value problems for ordinary differential equations.
math 51.requisite: Requisites: (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375) and (MATH322, 376, 421, or 521) and (COMPSCI200, 220, 300, 310, or 301 prior to Spring 2020) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 52.name: ORDINARY DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS
math 52.subject: Mathematics
math 52.description: Provides a rigorous introduction to ordinary differential equations and dynamical systems. Intended for math majors and advanced (or graduate) students in other disciplines.
math 52.requisite: Requisites: (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375) and (MATH322, 376, 421, or 521) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 53.name: ANALYSIS I
math 53.subject: Mathematics
math 53.description: The real numbers, elements of set theory, metric spaces and basic topology, sequences and series, limits, continuity, differentiation, integration, sequences and series of functions, uniform convergence.
math 53.requisite: Requisites: (MATH234 and 467) or (MATH322, 341, 376, 421) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 54.name: ANALYSIS II
math 54.subject: Mathematics
math 54.description: Special functions, power series, Fourier series, approximation, contraction principle, characterizations of compactness in metric spaces, applications to differential equations. Differential calculus in normed spaces, including implicit and inverse function theorems. Course is essential for graduate work in mathematics.
math 54.requisite: Requisites: MATH521 and (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 55.name: LINEAR OPTIMIZATION
math 55.subject: Mathematics
math 55.description: Introduces optimization problems whose constraints are expressed by linear inequalities. Develops geometric and algebraic insights into the structure of the problem, with an emphasis on formal proofs. Presents the theory behind the simplex method, the main algorithm used to solve linear optimization problems. Explores duality theory and theorems of the alternatives.
math 55.requisite: Requisites: MATH320, 340, 341, 375, or 443 or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 56.name: PROBABILITY THEORY
math 56.subject: Mathematics
math 56.description: A rigorous introduction to probability theory at an advanced undergraduate level. Only a minimal amount of measure theory is used, in particular, the theory of Lebesgue integrals is not needed. It is aimed at math majors and Master's degree students, or students in other fields who will need probability in their future careers. Gives an introduction to the basics (Kolmogorov axioms, conditional probability and independence, random variables, expectation) and discusses some classical results with proofs (DeMoivre-Laplace limit theorems, the study of simple random walk on the one dimensional lattice, applications of generating functions).
math 56.requisite: Requisites: MATH376, 421, or 521 or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 57.name: MATHEMATICAL METHODS IN DATA SCIENCE
math 57.subject: Mathematics
math 57.description: A rigorous introduction to mathematical concepts important for modern data science.   Topics include: matrix factorizations,  optimization theory and algorithms, probabilistic models, finite Markov chains.  Mathematical techniques are motivated by and illustrated on a range of applied problems from machine learning and statistics.
math 57.requisite: Requisites: (MATH320, 340, 341, 375 or ME/COMPSCI/ECE532) and (STAT/MATH309, 431, MATH531, STAT311 or ECE331) and (MATH322, 341, 375, 421, 467, or COMPSCI577), graduate/professional standing, or member of Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting Intl) Prgrm

math 58.name: LINEAR ALGEBRA II
math 58.subject: Mathematics
math 58.description: Review of linear transformations, duality. Diagonalization of linear transformations.The Cayley Hamilton Theorem. Minimal polynomials. The Jordan canonical form. Exponential function. Inner product spaces, orthonormal bases and Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization. Operators on inner product spaces. Self-adjoint, unitary and positive operators. Spectral theorem. singular value decomposition. Bilinear and quadratic forms. Norms, bounded linear operators, matrix norms. Basic multilinear algebra. This is a second course in linear algebra.
math 58.requisite: Requisites: (MATH234 or 375), (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375), and (MATH341, 375, 421, 467, or 521), or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 59.name: MODERN ALGEBRA
math 59.subject: Mathematics
math 59.description: Groups, normal subgroups, Cayley's theorem, rings, ideals, homomorphisms, polynomial rings, abstract vector spaces.
math 59.requisite: Requisites: (MATH234 or 375), (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375), and (MATH341, 375, 421, 467, or 521), or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 60.name: MODERN ALGEBRA
math 60.subject: Mathematics
math 60.description: Field extensions, roots of polynomials, splitting fields, simple extensions, linear transformations, matrices, characteristic roots, canonical forms, determinants.
math 60.requisite: Requisites: MATH541 or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 61.name: ELEMENTARY TOPOLOGY
math 61.subject: Mathematics
math 61.description: Topological spaces, connectedness, compactness, separation axioms, metric spaces.
math 61.requisite: Requisites: (MATH234 or 375), (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375), and (MATH341, 375, 421, 467, or 521), or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 62.name: ELEMENTARY GEOMETRIC AND ALGEBRAIC TOPOLOGY
math 62.subject: Mathematics
math 62.description: Introduction to algebraic topology. Emphasis on geometric aspects, including two-dimensional manifolds, the fundamental group, covering spaces, basic simplicial homology theory, the Euler-Poincare formula, and homotopy classes of mappings.
math 62.requisite: Requisites: (MATH551 and 541) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 63.name: DIFFERENTIAL GEOMETRY
math 63.subject: Mathematics
math 63.description: Theory of curves and surfaces by differential methods.
math 63.requisite: Requisites: (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375) and (MATH322, 376, 421, or 521) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 64.name: MODERN NUMBER THEORY
math 64.subject: Mathematics
math 64.description: A course in number theory covering fundamentals and modern applications in topics of recent interest: Modular arithmetic, quadratic reciprocity, arithmetic functions, zeta function, Diophantine equations, transcendental numbers, Roth's theorem, continued fractions, and the circle method. Optional material from probability including random matrix theory.
math 64.requisite: Requisites: MATH541 or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 65.name: FUNDAMENTALS OF SET THEORY
math 65.subject: Mathematics
math 65.description: Introduces the basic concepts of Set Theory including: Set-theoretical paradoxes and means of avoiding them, sets, relations, functions, orders and well-orders, proof by transfinite induction and definitions by transfinite recursion, cardinal and ordinal numbers and their arithmetic, construction of the real numbers, the axiom of choice and its consequences.
math 65.requisite: Requisites: (MATH234 and 467) or (MATH341, 375, 421 or 521) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 66.name: MATHEMATICAL LOGIC
math 66.subject: Mathematics
math 66.description: Basics of logic and mathematical proofs; propositional logic; first order logic; undecidability.
math 66.requisite: Requisites: (MATH234 or 375), (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375), and (MATH341, 375, 421, 467, or 521), or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 67.name: STOCHASTIC METHODS FOR BIOLOGY
math 67.subject: Mathematics
math 67.description: Intended to provide a rigorous foundation for stochastic modeling of biological systems. The mathematical emphasis is in stochastic analysis and simulation. Biological applications include epidemiological phenomena, biochemical reaction networks and population dynamics.
math 67.requisite: Requisites: (STAT/MATH431, 309, STAT311 or MATH531) and (MATH320, 340, 341, 375, 421 or 531) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 68.name: TOPICS IN MATHEMATICS STUDY ABROAD
math 68.subject: Mathematics
math 68.description: Credit is awarded to students who have completed an appropriate math course abroad at the advanced level having no direct equivalence within the math department offerings. The study abroad course must be pre-approved by the math department.

math 69.name: ANALYSIS OF PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS
math 69.subject: Mathematics
math 69.description: A rigorous introduction to the theoretical underpinnings of the basic methods and techniques in the modern theory of PDEs. It is aimed at math majors, but will also be useful to some students in the sciences, engineering and economics who feel the need for a deeper understanding of the theory of PDEs. The emphasis is on the exposure to a number of different methods of solution of PDEs and their connection to physical phenomena modeled by the equations. The goals include both learning to solve some basic types of PDEs as well as to understand the motivation behind and inner workings of the techniques involved.
math 69.requisite: Requisites: (MATH322, 421, or 521) and (MATH319, 320, 376, 415, or 519) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 70.name: INTRODUCTION TO MANIFOLDS
math 70.subject: Mathematics
math 70.description: Integration in Euclidean spaces, change of variables, multilinear algebra, vector fields and differential forms, manifolds and tangent spaces, integration on manifolds, Stokes theorem. Classical vector analysis. Cauchy integral theorem.
math 70.requisite: Requisites: MATH522, (MATH521 and 561), graduate/professional standing, or declared in Mathematics VISP

math 71.name: COMPLEX ANALYSIS
math 71.subject: Mathematics
math 71.description: Elementary functions of a complex variable; conformal mapping; complex integrals; the calculus of residues.
math 71.requisite: Requisites: MATH321 or 521 or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 72.name: INTRODUCTION TO FOURIER ANALYSIS
math 72.subject: Mathematics
math 72.description: Fourier series and integrals, and their applications.
math 72.requisite: Requisites: MATH521 or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 73.name: INTRODUCTION TO MEASURE AND INTEGRATION
math 73.subject: Mathematics
math 73.description: Lebesgue integral and measure, abstract measure and integration, differentiation, spaces of integrable functions.
math 73.requisite: Requisites: MATH522 or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 74.name: INTRODUCTION TO STOCHASTIC PROCESSES
math 74.subject: Mathematics
math 74.description: Topics include discrete-time Markov chains, Poisson point processes, continuous-time Markov chains, and renewal processes. Applications to queueing, branching, and other models in science, engineering and business.
math 74.requisite: Requisites: (STAT/MATH431, 309, STAT311 or MATH531) and (MATH320, 340, 341, 375, 421 or 531) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 75.name: AN INTRODUCTION TO BROWNIAN MOTION AND STOCHASTIC CALCULUS
math 75.subject: Mathematics
math 75.description: Presents an introduction to Brownian motion and its application to stochastic calculus. Sample path properties of Brownian motion, Ito stochastic integrals, Ito's formula, stochastic differential equations and properties of their solutions, and various applications will be included.
math 75.requisite: Requisites: (MATH521 and STAT/ISYE/MATH/OTM632) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 76.name: INTRODUCTION TO ERROR-CORRECTING CODES
math 76.subject: Mathematics
math 76.description: Coding theory. Codes (linear, Hamming, Golay, dual); decoding-encoding; Shannon's theorem; sphere-packing; singleton and Gilbert-Varshamov bounds; weight enumerators; MacWilliams identities; finite fields; other codes (Reed-Muller, cyclic, BCH, Reed-Solomon) and error-correction algorithms.
math 76.requisite: Requisites: MATH541 or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 77.name: SENIOR HONORS THESIS
math 77.subject: Mathematics
math 77.description: Individual study for honors math majors writing a thesis in mathematics.

math 78.name: SENIOR HONORS THESIS
math 78.subject: Mathematics
math 78.description: Individual study for honors math majors writing a thesis in mathematics.

math 79.name: UNDERGRADUATE THESIS
math 79.subject: Mathematics
math 79.description: Individual study for students writing a thesis in mathematics.

math 80.name: UNDERGRADUATE THESIS
math 80.subject: Mathematics
math 80.description: Individual study for students writing a thesis in mathematics.

math 81.name: DIRECTED STUDY
math 81.subject: Mathematics
math 81.description: Directed study projects as arranged with a faculty member.

math 82.name: DIRECTED STUDY
math 82.subject: Mathematics
math 82.description: Directed study projects as arranged with a faculty member.

math 83.name: METHODS OF APPLIED MATHEMATICS 1
math 83.subject: Mathematics
math 83.description: Study of the linear algebraic structure underlying discrete equilibrium problems. Boundary value problems for continous equilibria: Sturm-Liouville equations, Laplace's equation, Poisson's equation, and the equations for Stokes flow. Contour integration and conformal mapping. Applications of dynamics leading to initial value problems for ODEs and PDEs. Green's functions for ODEs and introduction to asymptotic methods for ODEs, e.g. WKB analysis. Separation of variables and eigenfunction expansions for linear PDEs. Examples from physics and engineering throughout. Knowledge of undergraduate linear algebra, analysis and complex analysis is strongly recommended.
math 83.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 84.name: METHODS OF APPLIED MATHEMATICS-2
math 84.subject: Mathematics
math 84.description: Derivation, nature and solution of canonical partial differential equations of applied mathematics. Conservation laws, advection, diffusion. First order PDEs, characteristics, shocks. Traffic flow, eikonal and Hamilton-Jacobi equations. Higher order PDEs: classification, Fourier analysis, well-posedness. Series solutions and integral transforms. Green's functions and distributions. Similarity solutions. Asymptotics of Fourier integrals. Laplace's method, stationary phase. Ship waves. Perturbation methods. Knowledge of undergraduate linear algebra, analysis and complex analysis is strongly recommended.
math 84.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 85.name: MATHEMATICAL FLUID DYNAMICS
math 85.subject: Mathematics
math 85.description: Advanced introduction to fluid dynamics. Basic concepts; elementary viscous flow; Navier-Stokes equations. Elementary airfoil theory; boundary layers. Vortex motion. Waves. Very viscous flow. Compressible flows. Instabilities, bifurcations, turbulence. Requires working knowledge of multivariate calculus, differential equations and mechanics.
math 85.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 86.name: MATHEMATICAL STATISTICS
math 86.subject: Mathematics
math 86.description: Introduction to measure theoretic probability; derivation and transformation of probability distributions; generating functions and characteristic functions; conditional expectation, sufficiency, and unbiased estimation; methods of large sample theory including laws of large numbers and central limit theorems; order statistics.

math 87.name: MATHEMATICAL STATISTICS
math 87.subject: Mathematics
math 87.description: Estimation, efficiency, Neyman-Pearson theory of hypothesis testing, confidence regions, decision theory, analysis of variance, and distribution of quadratic forms.

math 88.name: METHODS OF COMPUTATIONAL MATHEMATICS I
math 88.subject: Mathematics
math 88.description: Development of finite difference methods for hyperbolic, parabolic and elliptic partial differential equations. Analysis of accuracy and stability of difference schemes. Direct and iterative methods for solving linear systems. Introduction to finite volume methods. Applications from science and engineering. Students are strongly encouraged to have programming skills (e.g. COMPSCI200) and some undergraduate numerical analysis (e.g. MATH/COMPSCI514 or COMPSCI412), analysis and differential equations (e.g. MATH322 and MATH521) and linear algebra (e.g. MATH341).
math 88.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 89.name: METHODS OF COMPUTATIONAL MATHEMATICS II
math 89.subject: Mathematics
math 89.description: Introduction to spectral methods (Fourier, Chebyshev, Fast Fourier Transform), finite element methods (Galerkin methods, energy estimates and error analysis), and mesh-free methods (Monte-Carlo, smoothed-particle hydrodynamics) for solving partial differential equations. Applications from science and engineering. Applications from science and engineering. Students are strongly encouraged to have programming skills (e.g. COMPSCI200), undergraduate numerical analysis (e.g. MATH/COMPSCI514 or COMPSCI412), analysis (MATH322 and math 521) and linear algebra (e.g. MATH341 or equiv.)
math 89.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 90.name: ORDINARY DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS
math 90.subject: Mathematics
math 90.description: Existence, uniqueness, and continuous dependence theorems, linear systems, stability, singular points, and boundary value problems. Qualitative behavior of nonlinear equations, stability, Lyapunov functions, invariant manifolds, bifurcation theory, periodic orbits, and connecting orbits.
math 90.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 91.name: STOCHASTIC COMPUTATIONAL METHODS
math 91.subject: Mathematics
math 91.description: Introduction to computational methods that use stochastic algorithms and/or methods that are applied to random or stochastic mathematical problems. The main emphasis will be placed on learning practical tools, while some aspects of theoretical foundations will also be covered (e.g., basic error analysis for numerical solution of stochastic differential equations (SDEs), and basic convergence of Monte Carlo methods). Topics include Monte Carlo methods, Bayesian inference and Bayesian sampling, simulation of Markov chains, numerical analysis for SDEs, data assimilation / state estimation, stochastic optimization methods and random sketching. Applications to science, engineering, finance, data science, and other practical problems also included.
math 91.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or declared in Mathematics Visiting International Student Program (graduate or dissertator)

math 92.name: PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS
math 92.subject: Mathematics
math 92.description: Classical theory of partial differential equations, together with an introduction to the modern theory based on functional analysis. Familiarity with basic measure theory (e.g. MATH629 or 721) or concurrent registration in MATH721 is strongly recommended.
math 92.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 93.name: PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS
math 93.subject: Mathematics
math 93.description: Initial value problems in partial differential equations, beginning with linear parabolic and hyperbolic equations, and continuing with nonlinear initial value problems.

math 94.name: A FIRST COURSE IN REAL ANALYSIS
math 94.subject: Mathematics
math 94.description: Real analysis concentrating on measures, integration, and differentiation and including an introduction to Hilbert spaces. Knowledge of undergraduate analysis (e.g. the sequence MATH521 and 522) is strongly recommended.
math 94.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 95.name: COMPLEX ANALYSIS
math 95.subject: Mathematics
math 95.description: The basic theory of functions of one complex variable including Cauchy formula, singularities and residues, meromorphic functions, conformal mappings, harmonic functions, approximation and the nonhomogeneous d-bar equation. Requires knowledge of undergraduate analysis (e.g. the sequence MATH521/522).
math 95.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 96.name: A SECOND COURSE IN REAL ANALYSIS
math 96.subject: Mathematics
math 96.description: Continuation of MATH721. An introduction to further topics in real analysis: Banach spaces, Fourier transforms, elements of distribution theory, and applications.
math 96.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 97.name: NONLINEAR OPTIMIZATION I
math 97.subject: Mathematics
math 97.description: Theory and algorithms for nonlinear optimization, focusing on unconstrained optimization. Line-search and trust-region methods; quasi-Newton methods; conjugate-gradient and limited-memory methods for large-scale problems; derivative-free optimization; algorithms for least-squares problems and nonlinear equations; gradient projection algorithms for bound-constrained problems; and simple penalty methods for nonlinearly constrained optimization. Students are strongly encouraged to have knowledge of linear algebra and familiarity with basic mathematical analysis.

math 98.name: INTEGER OPTIMIZATION
math 98.subject: Mathematics
math 98.description: Introduces optimization problems over integers, and surveys the theory behind the algorithms used in state-of-the-art methods for solving such problems. Special attention is given to the polyhedral formulations of these problems, and to their algebraic and geometric properties. Applicability of Integer Optimization is highlighted with applications in combinatorial optimization. Key topics include: formulations, relaxations, polyhedral theory, cutting planes, decomposition, enumeration.  Students are strongly encouraged to have knowledge of Linear Programming  (e.g., MATH/COMPSCI/ISYE/STAT525), including algorithms, duality and polyhedral theory.

math 99.name: NONLINEAR OPTIMIZATION II
math 99.subject: Mathematics
math 99.description: Theory and algorithms for nonlinearly constrained optimization. Relevant geometric concepts, including tangent and normal cones, theorems of the alternative, and separation results. Constraint qualifications. Geometric and algebraic expression of first-order optimality conditions. Second-order optimality conditions. Duality. Nonlinear  programming algorithms: merit functions and filters; interior-point, augmented Lagrangian, and sequential quadratic programming algorithms.

math 100.name: THEORY OF PROBABILITY I
math 100.subject: Mathematics
math 100.description: An introduction to measure theoretic probability and stochastic processes.Topics include foundations, independence, zero-one laws, laws of large numbers, convergence in distribution, characteristic functions, central limit theorems, random walks, conditional expectations. Familiarity with basic measure theory (e.g. MATH629 or 721) or concurrent registration in MATH721 is strongly recommended.
math 100.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 101.name: THEORY OF PROBABILITY II
math 101.subject: Mathematics
math 101.description: Continuation of MATH/STAT733. Possible topics include martingales, weak convergence of measures, introduction to Brownian motion.
math 101.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 102.name: STOCHASTIC ANALYSIS
math 102.subject: Mathematics
math 102.description: Foundations of continuous time stochastic processes, semimartingales and the semimartingale integral, Ito's formula, stochastic differential equations, stochastic equations for Markov processes, application in finance, filtering, and control. The course relies on measure theoretic probability theory that can be reviewed at the beginning of the semester.
math 102.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 103.name: ENUMERATIVE COMBINATORICS/SYMMETRIC FUNCTIONS
math 103.subject: Mathematics
math 103.description: Inclusion-exclusion principle, permutation statistics, sieve methods, unimodal sequences, posets, lattice theory, Mobius functions, generating functions, bases and transition matrices for symmetric functions, Young tableaux, plane partitions, polytopes, poset homology, Stanley-Reisner rings.
math 103.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 104.name: ABSTRACT ALGEBRA
math 104.subject: Mathematics
math 104.description: Usually a study of finite groups and noncommutative rings. Group theoretic topics may include: permutation groups, Lagrange's theorem, Cauchy's theorem and the Sylow theorems, solvable and nilpotent groups. Ring theoretic topics may include: Artinian rings and modules, the Wedderburn theorems, the Hopkins-Levitzki theorem, the Jacobson radical and density theorem. The basic prerequisite for all advanced graduate courses in algebra.  Familiarity with topics in undergraduate algebra (e.g. MATH541 and 542) is strongly recommended.
math 104.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 105.name: ABSTRACT ALGEBRA
math 105.subject: Mathematics
math 105.description: Continuation of MATH741. Usually the study of commutative rings and fields. Ring theoretic topics may include: modules over PIDs, Noetherian rings and the Hilbert basis theorem, the Lasker-Noether theorem, the Krull intersection theorem, integrality and the Hilbert Nullstellensatz. Field theoretic topics may include: algebraic extensions, Galois theory, solvability of polynomials and classical constructability problems.
math 105.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 106.name: TOPICS IN RING THEORY
math 106.subject: Mathematics
math 106.description: Will alternate between commutative and noncommutative ring theory. Commutative topics include localization; local rings; dimension theory; Cohen-Macaulay rings. Noncommutative topics include projective modules; injective modules; flat modules; homological and global dimension; Wedderburn and Goldie rings. Basic graduate algebra courses (e.g. MATH741 and 742) are strongly recommended.
math 106.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 107.name: LIE ALGEBRAS
math 107.subject: Mathematics
math 107.description: Lie algebras and matrix groups. Topics: tangent spaces; exponentials; Baker-Campbell-Hausdorff formula; (nilpotent, solvable, semisimple) Lie algebras; Engel's and Lie's theorems; Levi decomposition; Killing form; sl(2)-representations; root systems; Dynkin diagrams; Weyl groups; Cartan and Borel subalgebras; Serre's theorem. Basic graduate algebra courses (e.g. MATH541 and 542 or MATH741 and 742) are strongly recommended.
math 107.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 108.name: ALGEBRAIC NUMBER THEORY
math 108.subject: Mathematics
math 108.description: A rigorous introduction to the arithmetic of number fields; algebraic integers, geometry of numbers, Dirichlet's Unit Theorem, ideal class groups, first case of Fermat's Last Theorem; prime decompositions, Galois automorphisms. Basic graduate algebra courses (e.g. MATH741 and 742) are strongly recommended.
math 108.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 109.name: ANALYTIC NUMBER THEORY
math 109.subject: Mathematics
math 109.description: An introduction to (abelian) Hecke L-functions and their arithmetic applications to topics such as the distribution of primes and the study of ideal class groups. Basic graduate algebra courses (e.g. MATH741 and 742) are strongly recommended
math 109.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 110.name: HOMOLOGICAL ALGEBRA
math 110.subject: Mathematics
math 110.description: Topics include: complexes, cohomology, double complexes, spectral sequences; abelian categories, derived categories, derived functors; Tor and Ext, Koszul complexes; group cohomology; sheaf cohomology, hypercohomology. Basic graduate algebra courses (e.g. MATH741 and 742) are strongly recommended
math 110.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 111.name: INTRODUCTORY TOPOLOGY I
math 111.subject: Mathematics
math 111.description: An introduction to algebraic and differential topology. Elements of homotopy theory, fundamental group, covering spaces. Differentiable manifolds, tangent vectors, regular values, transversality, examples of compact Lie groups. Homological algebra, chain complexes, cell complexes, singular and cellular homology, calculations for surfaces, spheres, projective spaces, etc. Familiarity with undergraduate algebra and topology MATH541 or 551) is strongly recommended.
math 111.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 112.name: INTRODUCTORY TOPOLOGY II
math 112.subject: Mathematics
math 112.description: Continuation of MATH751. Cohomology, Universal Coefficient Theorem, Kunneth Formula, cup and cap products, applications to manifolds, orientability, Poincare Duality. Differential forms, integration and Stokes Theorem, De Rham Theorem. Calculations, further duality theorems, Euler class, Lefschetz Fixed-Point Theorem.
math 112.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 113.name: ALGEBRAIC TOPOLOGY I
math 113.subject: Mathematics
math 113.description: Higher homotopy groups, elements of obstruction theory, fibrations, bundle theory, classifying spaces, applications to smooth mainfolds, differential forms, vector bundles, characteristic classes, cobordism, applications and calculations. Basic graduate topology courses (e.g. MATH751 and 752) are strongly recommended.
math 113.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 114.name: ALGEBRAIC TOPOLOGY II
math 114.subject: Mathematics
math 114.description: Continuation of MATH753. Topics include: spectral sequences and their applications, topology of Lie Groups, H-spaces, Hopf Algebras, homotopy classification of bundles, the Steenrod Algebra and its applications, intorduction to generalized cohomology theories, spectra, elements of K-theory.
math 114.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 115.name: DIFFERENTIABLE MANIFOLDS
math 115.subject: Mathematics
math 115.description: Differentiable manifolds, vector bundles, implicit function theorem, submersions and immersions, vector fields and flows, foliations and Frobenius theorem, differential forms and exterior calculus, integration and Stokes' theorem, De Rham theory, Riemannian metrics. Familiarity with basic undergraduate analysis courses MATH521 and 522 or MATH621) is strongly recommended.
math 115.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 116.name: INTRODUCTION TO ALGEBRAIC GEOMETRY
math 116.subject: Mathematics
math 116.description: Algebraic preliminaries, including local rings; valuation theory, and power series rings; geometry of algebraic varieties with emphasis on curves and surfaces.
math 116.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 117.name: INTRODUCTION TO ALGEBRAIC GEOMETRY
math 117.subject: Mathematics
math 117.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 118.name: DIFFERENTIAL GEOMETRY
math 118.subject: Mathematics
math 118.description: Covers the metric properties of Riemannian manifolds. The following topics will be covered: Vector bundles and connections, Riemannian metrics, submanifolds and second fundamental form, first variation of arc length, geodesics, Hopf-Rinow theorem, second variation of arc length, Jacobi fields and index lemmas, Bonnet-Meyer theorem, Rauch comparison theorem, spaces of constant curvature, Hodge-de Rham theory. Familiarity with the topics in a differential manifolds course (e.g. MATH761) is strongly recommended.
math 118.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 119.name: FOUNDATIONS OF MATHEMATICS
math 119.subject: Mathematics
math 119.description: First-order logic syntax and semantics, Completeness and Compactness Theorems, Lowenheim-Skolem Theorem, computable and computably enumerable sets, Incompleteness Theorem, axioms of Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory with choice, ordinal and cardinal arithmetic.
math 119.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 120.name: SET THEORY
math 120.subject: Mathematics
math 120.description: Martin's Axiom, Suslin and Aronszajn trees, diamond principle, absoluteness and reflection, constructible universe, and one-step forcing constructions. Familiarity with the topics in a basic Foundations course such as MATH770 is strongly recommended.
math 120.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 121.name: COMPUTABILITY THEORY
math 121.subject: Mathematics
math 121.description: Turing degree and jump, strong reducibilities, arithmetic hierarchy, index sets, simple and (hyper)hypersimple sets, easy forcing arguments in computability theory, finite and infinite injury, Friedberg-Muchnik and Sacks Splitting Theorem, Sacks Jump and Sacks Density Theorems, computable ordinals. Familiarity with the topics in a basic Foundations course such as MATH770 is strongly recommended.
math 121.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 122.name: MODEL THEORY
math 122.subject: Mathematics
math 122.description: Review of compactness and some consequences. Quantifier elimination with examples. The omitting types theorem. Categoricity. Baldwin-Lachlan theory. Strongly minimal and o-minimal theories. Saturated models. Morley's theorem. Familiarity with the topics in a basic Foundations course such as MATH770 is strongly recommended.
math 122.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 123.name: NONLINEAR DYNAMICS, BIFURCATIONS AND CHAOS
math 123.subject: Mathematics
math 123.description: Advanced interdisciplinary introduction to qualitative and geometric methods for dissipative nonlinear dynamical systems. Local bifurcations of ordinary differential equations and maps. Chaotic attractors, horseshoes and detection of chaos.
math 123.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 124.name: MASTERS THESIS
math 124.subject: Mathematics
math 124.description: Work on a Master's thesis under the supervision of a faculty member.
math 124.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 125.name: TOPICS IN APPLIED MATHEMATICS
math 125.subject: Mathematics
math 125.description: Selected topics in applied mathematics, applied analysis or numerical analysis and scientific computing.
math 125.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 126.name: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN I
math 126.subject: Mathematics
math 126.description: Summary of matrix algebra required, theory of estimable functions, incomplete blocks, balanced incomplete block designs, partially balanced incomplete block designs.
math 126.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 127.name: DYNAMICAL SYSTEMS
math 127.subject: Mathematics
math 127.description: Treats the qualitative behavior of continuous and discrete dynamical systems, including Hamiltonian systems of differential equations. Typical topics include periodic and almost periodic solutions, the fixed point theorem of Poincare and Birkhoff, invariant curves and KAM theory, celestial mechanics, and chaotic behavior.
math 127.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 128.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN REAL ANALYSIS
math 128.subject: Mathematics
math 128.description: Topics in partial differential equations and real analysis.
math 128.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 129.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN COMPLEX ANALYSIS
math 129.subject: Mathematics
math 129.description: Several complex variables. Basic several complex variables or more special topics.
math 129.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 130.name: SELECTED TOPICS IN FUNCTIONAL ANALYSIS
math 130.subject: Mathematics
math 130.description: Topics will vary and may include spectral theory, nonlinear functional analysis or abstract harmonic analysis.
math 130.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 131.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN FUNCTIONAL ANALYSIS AND DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS
math 131.subject: Mathematics
math 131.description: Topics in functional analysis and differential equations.
math 131.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 132.name: FOURIER ANALYSIS
math 132.subject: Mathematics
math 132.description: Introduction to Fourier analysis in Euclidean spaces and related topics that may include singular and oscillatory integrals and trigonometric series.
math 132.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 133.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN HARMONIC ANALYSIS
math 133.subject: Mathematics
math 133.description: Continuation of MATH827. Advanced topics in harmonic analysis.
math 133.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 134.name: TOPICS IN THE THEORY OF PROBABILITY
math 134.subject: Mathematics
math 134.description: Advanced topics in probability and stochastic processes.
math 134.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 135.name: TOPICS IN APPLIED ALGEBRA
math 135.subject: Mathematics
math 135.description: Applied topics with emhasis on algebraic constructions and structures. Examples include: algebraic coding theory; codes (algebraic-geometric, convolutional, low-density-parity-check, space-time); curve and lattice based cryptography; watermarking; computer vision (face recognition, multiview geometry).
math 135.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 136.name: REPRESENTATION THEORY
math 136.subject: Mathematics
math 136.description: Introduction to the representation theory of Lie groups and their combinatorics. Universal enveloping algebras, highest weight modules, induction, restriction, weights, characters, multiplicity formulas, tensor products, Shapovalov forms, filtrations,  Kazhdan-Zetlin patterns, Littelmann paths.
math 136.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 137.name: ARITHMETIC GEOMETRY
math 137.subject: Mathematics
math 137.description: An introduction to arithmetic geometry with emphasis on arithmetic of elliptic curves.
math 137.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 138.name: CLASS FIELD THEORY
math 138.subject: Mathematics
math 138.description: Introduction to local and global class field theory. Theory of local fields; local and global class field theory; complex multiplication, adeles, ideles, idele class characters, Tchebotarev's Density Theorem, CM elliptic curves, construction of class fields of imaginary quadratic fields.
math 138.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 139.name: TOPICS IN COMBINATORICS
math 139.subject: Mathematics
math 139.description: Topics in algebraic combinatorics such as (but not limited to) association schemes, hypergeometric series, classical orthogonal polynomials, codes,  lattices, invariant theory, alternating sign matrices and domino tilings, statistical mechanical models, 6j-symbols, buildings and diagram geometries, matroids.
math 139.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 140.name: TOPICS IN ALGEBRA
math 140.subject: Mathematics
math 140.description: Topics may include: Lie groups, algebraic groups, Chevalley groups, simple groups and associated geometries, group cohomology, group rings, Hopf algebras, enveloping algebras, quantum groups, infinite-dimensional Lie algebras, Hecke algebras, automorphic forms, Galois representations, zeta and L-functions, abelian varieties.
math 140.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 141.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN NUMBER THEORY
math 141.subject: Mathematics
math 141.description: This is an advanced graduate topic course in number theory. Topics will vary. Target audience: Advanced graduate students in number theory, representation theory, and algebraic geometry.
math 141.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 142.name: AUTOMORPHIC FORMS
math 142.subject: Mathematics
math 142.description: Classical and/or modern theory of automorphic forms. Representation theory of GL(2).
math 142.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 143.name: TOPICS IN GEOMETRIC TOPOLOGY
math 143.subject: Mathematics
math 143.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 144.name: TOPICS IN ALGEBRAIC TOPOLOGY
math 144.subject: Mathematics
math 144.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 145.name: TOPICS IN DIFFERENTIAL TOPOLOGY
math 145.subject: Mathematics
math 145.description: The theory of differential manifolds such as differential forms and de Rham theorem, cobordism groups, Lie groups, homogeneous spaces, fiber bundles, characteristic classes.
math 145.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 146.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN ALGEBRAIC GEOMETRY
math 146.subject: Mathematics
math 146.description: Geometry of several complex variables; algebraic groups, abelian varieties; topological aspects of algebraic geometry, including sheaf theory and homology theory; advanced theory of local rings; intersection theory of algebraic varieties.
math 146.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 147.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN GEOMETRY
math 147.subject: Mathematics
math 147.description: Selected from advanced projective geometry, non-Euclidean geometry, Riemannian geometry, distance geometry and the geometry of convex surfaces, geometry of numbers.
math 147.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 148.name: ANALYTIC NUMBER THEORY
math 148.subject: Mathematics
math 148.description: Prime number theory, prime number theory for arithmetic progressions, additive number theory, density theorems.
math 148.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 149.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN FOUNDATIONS
math 149.subject: Mathematics
math 149.description: Advanced topics from all areas of mathematical logic.
math 149.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 150.name: TOPICS IN MATHEMATICAL DATA SCIENCE
math 150.subject: Mathematics
math 150.description: Advanced topics in the mathematical foundations of data science
math 150.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 151.name: GRADUATE TEACHING SEMINAR
math 151.subject: Mathematics
math 151.description: Focuses on theory and practical skills relevant to teaching mathematics at the graduate or post-secondary level.

math 152.name: SEMINAR IN ANALYSIS
math 152.subject: Mathematics
math 152.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 153.name: SEMINAR-ALGEBRA
math 153.subject: Mathematics
math 153.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 154.name: SEMINAR IN TOPOLOGY
math 154.subject: Mathematics
math 154.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 155.name: SEMINAR IN NUMBER THEORY
math 155.subject: Mathematics
math 155.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 156.name: SEMINAR-THE FOUNDATIONS OF MATHEMATICS
math 156.subject: Mathematics
math 156.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

math 157.name: READING AND RESEARCH
math 157.subject: Mathematics
math 157.description: Reading and research in all areas of Mathematics.

stat 0.name: DATA SCIENCE MODELING I
stat 0.subject: Statistics
stat 0.description: Introduces reproducible data management, modeling, and analysis through a practical, hands-on case studies approach. Topics include the use of an integrated statistical computing environment, data wrangling, the R programming language, data graphics and visualization, random variables and concepts of probability, data modeling, and report generation using R Markdown with applications to a wide variety of data to address open-ended questions.
stat 0.requisite: Requisites: Satisfied Quantitative Reasoning (QR) A requirement

stat 1.name: INTRODUCTION TO STATISTICAL METHODS
stat 1.subject: Statistics
stat 1.description: Distributions, measures of central tendency, dispersion and shape, the normal distribution; experiments to compare means, standard errors, confidence intervals; effects of departure from assumption; method of least squares, regression, correlation, assumptions and limitations; basic ideas of experimental design.
stat 1.requisite: Requisites: Satisfied Quantitative Reasoning (QR) A requirement. Not open to students with credit for STAT302, 324, or 371

stat 2.name: ACCELERATED INTRODUCTION TO STATISTICAL METHODS
stat 2.subject: Statistics
stat 2.description: Graphical and numerical exploration of data; standard errors; distributions for statistical models including binomial, Poisson, normal; estimation; hypothesis testing; randomization tests; basic principles of experimental design; regression; ANOVA; categorical data analysis; goodness of fit; application.
stat 2.requisite: Requisites: MATH217, 221, or 275. Not open to students who have completed STAT324, or 371

stat 3.name: R FOR STATISTICS I
stat 3.subject: Statistics
stat 3.description: An understanding of the commonly used statistical language R. Topics will include using R to manipulate data and perform exploratory data analysis.
stat 3.requisite: Requisites: STAT240, 301, 302, 312, 324, 371, MATH/STAT310, ECON310, GEN BUS 303, 304, 306, 307, PSYCH210, SOC/C&ESOC360, graduate/professional standing, or declared in Statistics VISP

stat 4.name: R FOR STATISTICS II
stat 4.subject: Statistics
stat 4.description: Provides an understanding of the commonly used statistical language R. Topics will include writing conditional expressions, loops, and functions; manipulating data matrices and arrays; extracting data from text; and making high level visualizations of data.
stat 4.requisite: Requisites: STAT303 (or STAT327-Intro Data Analysis with R prior to Fall 2019)

stat 5.name: R FOR STATISTICS III
stat 5.subject: Statistics
stat 5.description: Provides an understanding of the commonly used statistical language R. Students will learn to combine R with high performance computing tools to do scientific computing.
stat 5.requisite: Requisites: STAT304 (or STAT327-Intermed. Data Analysis with R prior to Fall 2019)

stat 6.name: INTRODUCTION TO PROBABILITY AND MATHEMATICAL STATISTICS I
stat 6.subject: Statistics
stat 6.description: Probability and combinatorial methods, discrete and continuous, univariate and multivariate distributions, expected values, moments, normal distribution and derived distributions, estimation.
stat 6.requisite: Requisites: MATH234, 376, or concurrent enrollment. Not open to students with credit for STAT/MATH431 or STAT311

stat 7.name: INTRODUCTION TO PROBABILITY AND MATHEMATICAL STATISTICS II
stat 7.subject: Statistics
stat 7.description: Mathematical statistical inference aims at providing an understanding of likelihood's central role to statistical inference, using the language of mathematical statistics to analyze statistical procedures, and using the computer as a tool for understanding statistics. Specific topics include: samples and populations, estimation, hypothesis testing, and theoretical properties of statistical inference.
stat 7.requisite: Requisites: (STAT/MATH309, STAT311, STAT/MATH431, or MATH531) and (STAT240, STAT301, STAT302, STAT324, STAT371, or ECON310), or graduate/professional standing

stat 8.name: INTRODUCTION TO THEORY AND METHODS OF MATHEMATICAL STATISTICS I
stat 8.subject: Statistics
stat 8.description: Elements of probability, important discrete distributions, acceptance sampling by attributes, sample characteristics, probability distributions and population characteristics, the normal distribution, acceptance sampling plans based on sample means and variances, sampling from the normal, the central limit theorem, point and interval estimation.
stat 8.requisite: Requisites: MATH234, 376, or concurrent enrollment or graduate/professsional standing. Not open to students with credit for STAT/MATH309 or STAT/MATH431

stat 9.name: INTRODUCTION TO THEORY AND METHODS OF MATHEMATICAL STATISTICS II
stat 9.subject: Statistics
stat 9.description: Unbiased estimation, maximum likelihood estimation, confidence intervals, tests of hypotheses, Neyman-Pearson lemma, likelihood ratio test, regression, analysis of variance with applications.
stat 9.requisite: Requisites: STAT/MATH309, STAT311, STAT/MATH431, MATH531, or graduate/professional standing

stat 10.name: INTRODUCTORY APPLIED STATISTICS FOR ENGINEERS
stat 10.subject: Statistics
stat 10.description: Descriptive statistics, probability concepts and distributions, random variables. Hypothesis tests and confidence intervals for one- and two-sample problems. Linear regression, model checking, and inference. Analysis of variance and basic ideas in experimental design.
stat 10.requisite: Requisites: MATH211, 217, 221, or 275. Not open to students with credit for STAT302 or 371

stat 11.name: LEARNING A STATISTICAL LANGUAGE
stat 11.subject: Statistics
stat 11.description: Introduction to commonly used statistical languages. (Two such languages commonly used in our Department -- and others -- are R and SAS.) Modules will be offered at the introductory, intermediate and advanced levels. Repeatable with different titles.
stat 11.requisite: Requisites: STAT301, 302, 324, 371, graduate/professional standing, or declared in Statistics VISP

stat 12.name: APPLIED REGRESSION ANALYSIS
stat 12.subject: Statistics
stat 12.description: An introduction to regression with emphasis on the practical aspects. Topics include: straight-line model, role of assumptions, residual analysis, transformations, multiple regression (with some use of matrix notation), multicollinearity, subset selection, and a brief introduction to mixed models.
stat 12.requisite: Requisites: (STAT240, 301, 302, 312, 324, or 371) and (STAT327 or 303, or concurrent enrollment)

stat 13.name: DATA SCIENCE MODELING II
stat 13.subject: Statistics
stat 13.description: Teaches how to apply statistical methods to learn from data. Topics include one- and two-sample inference; an introduction to Bayesian inference and associated probability theory; linear and logistic regression models; the bootstrap; and cross-validation. An integrated statistical computing environment is used to explore and analyze data, develop models, make inferences, and communicate results in a reproducible manner through a project-oriented approach to learning.

stat 14.name: INTRODUCTION TO TIME SERIES
stat 14.subject: Statistics
stat 14.description: Autocorrelation; stationarity and non-stationarity; heteroscedasticity; dynamic models; auto-regressive and moving average models; identification and fitting; forecasting; seasonal adjustment; applications for financial time series, social sciences and environmental studies.
stat 14.requisite: Requisites: STAT333, 340, graduate/professional standing, or declared in Statistics VISP

stat 15.name: INTRODUCTORY NONPARAMETRIC STATISTICS
stat 15.subject: Statistics
stat 15.description: Distribution free statistical procedures or methods valid under nonrestrictive assumptions: basic tools; counting methods; order statistics, ranks, empirical distribution functions; distribution free tests and associated interval and point estimators; sign test; signed rank tests; rank tests; Mann Whitney Wilcoxon procedures; Kolmogorov Smirnov tests; permutation methods; kernel density estimation; kernel and spline regression estimation; computer techniques and programs; discussion and comparison with parametric methods.
stat 15.requisite: Requisites: STAT333, 340, graduate/professional standing, or declared in Statistics VISP

stat 16.name: TOPICS IN STATISTICS STUDY ABROAD
stat 16.subject: Statistics
stat 16.description: Credit is awarded for students having completed an advanced statistics course in a study abroad program for which there is no direct equivalence to the statistics department course offerings. The study abroad course must be pre-approved by the statistics department.

stat 17.name: INTERNSHIP COURSE IN COMP SCI AND DATA SCIENCE
stat 17.subject: Statistics
stat 17.description: Enables students with outside internships to earn academic credit connected to their work experience related to the Computer Sciences or Data Science programs.

stat 18.name: DATA SCIENCE COMPUTING PROJECT
stat 18.subject: Statistics
stat 18.description: The development of tools necessary for collecting, managing, and analyzing large data sets. Examples of techniques and programs used include Linux, R, distributed computing, text editor(s), git/github, and other related tools. Work in teams to research, develop, write, and make presentations related to a variety of data analysis projects.
stat 18.requisite: Requisites: (STAT240 or 303) and (COMPSCI200, 220, or 300), or graduate/professional standing

stat 19.name: APPLIED CATEGORICAL DATA ANALYSIS
stat 19.subject: Statistics
stat 19.description: Analysis of multidimensional contingency tables, Poisson regression, and logistic regression, with emphasis on practical applications. Use of computer programs for such analyses. Model selection, testing goodness of fit, estimation of parameters, measures of association and methods for detecting sources of significance.
stat 19.requisite: Requisites: STAT333, 340, graduate/professional standing, or declared in Statistics VISP

stat 20.name: STATISTICAL EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN
stat 20.subject: Statistics
stat 20.description: Introduction to statistical design and analysis of experiments. Topics include: principles of randomization, blocking and replication, randomized blocking designs, Latin square designs, full factorial and fractional factorial designs and response surface methodology. Substantial focus will be devoted to engineering applications.

stat 21.name: INTRODUCTION TO THE THEORY OF PROBABILITY
stat 21.subject: Statistics
stat 21.description: Topics covered include axioms of probability, random variables, the most important discrete and continuous probability distributions, expectation and variance, moment generating functions, conditional probability and conditional expectations, multivariate distributions, Markov's and Chebyshev's inequalities, laws of large numbers, and the central limit theorem.
stat 21.requisite: Requisites: MATH234 or 376 or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

stat 22.name: DATA SCIENCE WITH R
stat 22.subject: Statistics
stat 22.description: Perform Data Science as an iterative (back and forth) process of four different types of activities (data collection, data wrangling, data analysis, communication). Traverse through the five requisite stances (scientist, coder, mathematician, methodologist, skeptic). Develop and hone a broad set of computational tools in R (but not the broadest) and a broad set of statistical/machine learning tools (but not the broadest). Focus on doing these with agility to make the coding "transparent" and serve the large goals of the project.
stat 22.requisite: Requisites: (STAT333 or 340) and (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375), graduate/professional standing, or declared in Statistics VISP

stat 23.name: STATISTICAL DATA VISUALIZATION
stat 23.subject: Statistics
stat 23.description: Techniques for visualization within data science workflows. Topics include data preparation; exploratory data analysis; spatial, tabular, and graph structured data; dimensionality reduction; model visualization and interpretability; interactive queries and navigation.
stat 23.requisite: Requisites: (STAT240 or 303), graduate professional/standing, or declared in Statistics VISP

stat 24.name: INTRODUCTION TO MACHINE LEARNING AND STATISTICAL PATTERN CLASSIFICATION
stat 24.subject: Statistics
stat 24.description: Introduction to machine learning for pattern classification, regression analysis, clustering, and dimensionality reduction. For each category, fundamental algorithms, as well as selections of contemporary, current state-of-the-art algorithms, are being discussed. The evaluation of machine learning models using statistical methods is a particular focus of this course. Statistical pattern classification approaches, including maximum likelihood estimation and Bayesian decision theory, are compared and contrasted to algorithmic and nonparametric approaches. While fundamental mathematical concepts underlying machine learning and pattern classification algorithms are being taught, the practical use of machine learning algorithms using open source libraries from the Python programming ecosystem will be of equal focus in this course.
stat 24.requisite: Requisites: MATH320, 321, 340, 341, graduate/professional standing, or declared in Statistics VISP

stat 25.name: INTRODUCTION TO DEEP LEARNING AND GENERATIVE MODELS
stat 25.subject: Statistics
stat 25.description: Deep learning is a field that specializes in discovering and extracting intricate structures in large, unstructured datasets for parameterizing artificial neural networks with many layers. Since deep learning has pushed the state-of-the-art in many research and application areas, it's become indispensable for modern technology. Focuses on a understanding deep, artificial neural networks by connecting it to related concepts in statistics. Beyond covering deep learning models for predictive modeling, focus on deep generative models. Besides explanations on a mathematical and conceptual level, emphasize the practical aspects of deep learning. Open-source computing provides hands-on experience for implementing deep neural nets, working on supervised learning tasks, and applying generative models for dataset synthesis.
stat 25.requisite: Requisites: MATH320, 321, 340, 341, graduate/professional standing, or declared in Statistics VISP

stat 26.name: APPLIED MULTIVARIATE ANALYSIS
stat 26.subject: Statistics
stat 26.description: Theory and applications of multivariate statistical methods. Basic concepts and statistical reasoning which underlie the techniques of multivariate analysis. Ideas rather than derivations stressed although basic models discussed to give the student some feeling for their adequacy in particular situations. Acquaintance with and use of existing computer programs in the multivariate analysis area.
stat 26.requisite: Requisites: (STAT333 or 340) and (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375), graduate/professional standing, or declared in Statistics VISP

stat 27.name: FINANCIAL STATISTICS
stat 27.subject: Statistics
stat 27.description: Stochastic models and statistical methodologies are widely employed in modern finance. The models and their inferences are very important for academic research and financial practices. This course will cover the financial stochastic models and their statistical inferences with applications to volatility analysis and risk management. It will introduce discrete models such as binomial trees and GARCH and stochastic volatility models as well as simple continuous models like the Black-Scholes model. The main focus of the course will be on statistical inference, data analysis and risk management regarding these models.
stat 27.requisite: Requisites: (STAT333 or 340 or ECON410) and (MATH/STAT309, STAT311, or MATH/STAT431), graduate/professional standing, or declared in Statistics VISP

stat 28.name: INTRODUCTION TO COMPUTATIONAL STATISTICS
stat 28.subject: Statistics
stat 28.description: Classical statistical procedures arise where closed-form mathematical expressions are available for various inference summaries (e.g. linear regression; analysis of variance). A major emphasis of modern statistics is the development of inference principles in cases where both more complex data structures are involved and where more elaborate computations are required. Topics from numerical linear algebra, optimization, Monte Carlo (including Markov chain Monte Carlo), and graph theory are developed, especially as they relate to statistical inference (e.g., bootstrapping, permutation, Bayesian inference, EM algorithm, multivariate analysis).
stat 28.requisite: Requisites: STAT/MATH310 and (STAT333 or 340), graduate/professional standing, or declared in Statistics VISP

stat 29.name: INTRODUCTION TO COMBINATORICS
stat 29.subject: Statistics
stat 29.description: Problems of enumeration, distribution, and arrangement. Inclusion-exclusion principle. Generating functions and linear recurrence relations. Combinatorial identities. Graph coloring problems. Finite designs. Systems of distinct representatives and matching problems in graphs. Potential applications in the social, biological, and physical sciences. Puzzles. Problem solving.
stat 29.requisite: Requisites: (MATH320, 340, 341, or 375) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

stat 30.name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN STATISTICS
stat 30.subject: Statistics
stat 30.description: Special topics of interest in undergraduate students.

stat 31.name: LINEAR OPTIMIZATION
stat 31.subject: Statistics
stat 31.description: Introduces optimization problems whose constraints are expressed by linear inequalities. Develops geometric and algebraic insights into the structure of the problem, with an emphasis on formal proofs. Presents the theory behind the simplex method, the main algorithm used to solve linear optimization problems. Explores duality theory and theorems of the alternatives.
stat 31.requisite: Requisites: MATH320, 340, 341, 375, or 443 or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

stat 32.name: INTRODUCTION TO BIOSTATISTICS
stat 32.subject: Statistics
stat 32.description: Course designed for the biomedical researcher. Topics include: descriptive statistics, hypothesis testing, estimation, confidence intervals, t-tests, chi-squared tests, analysis of variance, linear regression, correlation, nonparametric tests, survival analysis and odds ratio. Biomedical applications used for each topic.
