stat 32.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing. Not open to students with credit for STAT 511 or POPHLTH/BMI551

stat 33.name: INTRODUCTION TO CLINICAL TRIALS I
stat 33.subject: Statistics
stat 33.description: Intended for biomedical researchers interested in the design and analysis of clinical trials. Topics include definition of hypotheses, measures of effectiveness, sample size, randomization, data collection and monitoring, and issues in statistical analysis. Statistics graduate students should take  BMI/STAT641.

stat 34.name: PRACTICUM IN CLINICAL TRIAL DATA ANALYSIS AND INTERPRETATION
stat 34.subject: Statistics
stat 34.description: Provides practice in analysis and interpretation of existing datasets from national and international clinical trials in a variety of diseases. Students will develop a research question, review clinical protocols, and analyze available data to prepare a report.
stat 34.requisite: Requisites: (BMI/STAT541 or HORT/F&WECOL/STAT572) and (BMI/STAT542 or BMI/STAT641)

stat 35.name: STATISTICAL METHODS FOR BIOSCIENCE I
stat 35.subject: Statistics
stat 35.description: Descriptive statistics, distributions, one- and two-sample normal inference, power, one-way ANOVA, simple linear regression, categorical data, non-parametric methods; underlying assumptions and diagnostic work.

stat 36.name: STATISTICAL METHODS FOR BIOSCIENCE II
stat 36.subject: Statistics
stat 36.description: Polynomial regression, multiple regression, two-way ANOVA with and without interaction, split-plot design, subsampling, analysis of covariance, elementary sampling, introduction to bioassay.

stat 37.name: STATISTICAL METHODS FOR SPATIAL DATA
stat 37.subject: Statistics
stat 37.description: Detecting and quantifying spatial patterns and modeling in the presence of such patterns. Spatial Point Patterns: testing nonrandomness, simulating and characterizing patterns. Lattice Data: spatial autocorrelation and regression. Geostatistics: variograms, ordinary and universal kriging, inference, assessing assumptions, and extensions.
stat 37.requisite: Requisites: (STAT333 or 340) and ME/STAT424; or HORT/F&WECOL/STAT572

stat 38.name: STATISTICAL METHODS I
stat 38.subject: Statistics
stat 38.description: Provides a thorough grounding in modern statistical methods. The specific learning outcomes for the course are to understand data collection in context (how/why data were collected, key questions under study); explore data by effective graphical and numerical summaries; understand probability concepts and models as tools for studying random phenomena and for statistical inference; analyze data using appropriate, modern statistical models, methods, and software; understand the statistical concepts underlying methods; develop the ability to interpret results and critically evaluate the methods used; communicate data analysis and key findings in context.
stat 38.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professsional standing or member of the Statistics Visiting International program

stat 39.name: STATISTICAL METHODS II
stat 39.subject: Statistics
stat 39.description: Provides a thorough grounding in modern statistical methods. The specific learning outcomes for the course are to understand data collection in context (how/why data were collected, key questions under study); explore data by effective graphical and numerical summaries; understand probability concepts and models as tools for studying random phenomena and for statistical inference; analyze data using appropriate, modern statistical models, methods, and software; understand the statistical concepts underlying methods; develop the ability to interpret results and critically evaluate the methods used; communicate data analysis and key findings in context.

stat 40.name: DATA SCIENCE COMPUTING PROJECT
stat 40.subject: Statistics
stat 40.description: The development of tools necessary for collecting, managing, and analyzing large data sets. Examples of techniques and programs utilized include Linux, R, distributed computing, powerful editor(s), git/github, and other related tools. Work in the class will be done in teams to research, develop, write, and make presentations related to a variety of data analysis projects. Knowledge of R equivalent to STAT303, 304, and 305.
stat 40.requisite: Requisites: Enrolled in Statistics MS or Statistics Visiting International Program

stat 41.name: MATHEMATICAL STATISTICS I
stat 41.subject: Statistics
stat 41.description: Review of probability, random variables and vectors and their distributions, moments and inequalities, generating functions, transformations of random variables, sampling and distribution theory, convergence concepts for sequences of random variables, laws of large numbers, central limit and other limit theorems.
stat 41.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professsional standing or member of the Statistics Visiting International program

stat 42.name: INTRODUCTION TO STATISTICAL INFERENCE
stat 42.subject: Statistics
stat 42.description: Conditioning, distribution theory, approximation to distributions, modes of convergence, limit theorems, statistical models, parameter estimation, comparision of estimators, confidence sets, theory of hypothesis tests, introduction to Bayesian inference and nonparametric estimation.
stat 42.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professsional standing or member of the Statistics Visiting International program

stat 43.name: STATISTICAL MODELS FOR DATA SCIENCE
stat 43.subject: Statistics
stat 43.description: Probability, random variables and their distributions, joint and conditional distributions, moments and inequalities, generating functions, transformations of random variables, sampling and distribution theory, convergence concepts and limit theorems for sequences of random variables.
stat 43.requisite: Requisites: Declared in Data Science MS or Data Engineering MS

stat 44.name: PROFESSIONAL SKILLS IN DATA SCIENCE
stat 44.subject: Statistics
stat 44.description: Covers important aspects of professional development in statistics, including skills with internet tools, sophisticated use of statistical languages (such as R) and other emerging topics.
stat 44.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professsional standing or member of the Statistics Visiting International program

stat 45.name: DATA SCIENCE PRACTICUM
stat 45.subject: Statistics
stat 45.description: Provides an understanding of and experience with turning statistics concepts into practice through data science practicums inspired by realistic projects. Students will combine theory and methods expertise with communications skills to translate from a vaguely stated project description and complex data set into a concisely summarized analysis, including both written and graphical interpretation that can be used by decision makers in an organization. Graduate student in Statistics

stat 46.name: INTRODUCTION TO STOCHASTIC PROCESSES
stat 46.subject: Statistics
stat 46.description: Topics include discrete-time Markov chains, Poisson point processes, continuous-time Markov chains, and renewal processes. Applications to queueing, branching, and other models in science, engineering and business.
stat 46.requisite: Requisites: (STAT/MATH431, 309, STAT311 or MATH531) and (MATH320, 340, 341, 375, 421 or 531) or graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

stat 47.name: STATISTICAL METHODS FOR CLINICAL TRIALS
stat 47.subject: Statistics
stat 47.description: Statistical issues in the design of clinical trials, basic survival analysis, data collection and sequential monitoring. Intended for statistics graduate students; those with medical backgrounds should take STAT/BMI542.

stat 48.name: STATISTICAL METHODS FOR EPIDEMIOLOGY
stat 48.subject: Statistics
stat 48.description: Methods for analysis of case-control, cross sectional, and cohort studies. Covers epidemiologic study design, measures of association, rates, classical contingency table methods, and logistic and Poisson regression.

stat 49.name: INTRODUCTION TO STATISTICAL CONSULTING
stat 49.subject: Statistics
stat 49.description: Develop statistical consulting skills to be able to communicate design and analysis to non-technical research collaborators. Provides a supportive environment to experiment with statistical consulting in practice, which will sometimes be uncomfortable and strange. Consulting problems typically do not have a "right" answer, and mistakes are encouraged. Take risks in sharing developing ideas in class. Connections with external organizations, such as the private sector and government agencies, will be made through possible internship experiences.

stat 50.name: SENIOR HONORS THESIS
stat 50.subject: Statistics
stat 50.description: Mentored individual study for students writing honors thesis, as arranged with a faculty member.

stat 51.name: SENIOR HONORS THESIS
stat 51.subject: Statistics
stat 51.description: Mentored individual study for students writing honors thesis, as arranged with a faculty member.

stat 52.name: DIRECTED STUDY
stat 52.subject: Statistics
stat 52.description: Directed study projects as arranged with a faculty member.

stat 53.name: DIRECTED STUDY
stat 53.subject: Statistics
stat 53.description: Directed study projects as arranged with a faculty member.

stat 54.name: APPLIED TIME SERIES ANALYSIS, FORECASTING AND CONTROL I
stat 54.subject: Statistics
stat 54.description: Theory and application of discrete time series models illustrated with forecasting problems. Principles of iterative model building. Representation of dynamic relations by difference equations. Autoregressive integrated Moving Average models. Identification, fitting, diagnostic checking of models. Seasonal model application to forecasting in business, economics, ecology, and engineering used at each stage, which the student analyzes using computer programs which have been specially written and extensively tested.

stat 55.name: MATHEMATICAL STATISTICS
stat 55.subject: Statistics
stat 55.description: Introduction to measure theoretic probability; derivation and transformation of probability distributions; generating functions and characteristic functions; conditional expectation, sufficiency, and unbiased estimation; methods of large sample theory including laws of large numbers and central limit theorems; order statistics.

stat 56.name: MATHEMATICAL STATISTICS
stat 56.subject: Statistics
stat 56.description: Estimation, efficiency, Neyman-Pearson theory of hypothesis testing, confidence regions, decision theory, analysis of variance, and distribution of quadratic forms.

stat 57.name: NONLINEAR OPTIMIZATION I
stat 57.subject: Statistics
stat 57.description: Theory and algorithms for nonlinear optimization, focusing on unconstrained optimization. Line-search and trust-region methods; quasi-Newton methods; conjugate-gradient and limited-memory methods for large-scale problems; derivative-free optimization; algorithms for least-squares problems and nonlinear equations; gradient projection algorithms for bound-constrained problems; and simple penalty methods for nonlinearly constrained optimization. Students are strongly encouraged to have knowledge of linear algebra and familiarity with basic mathematical analysis.

stat 58.name: LARGE SAMPLE THEORY OF STATISTICAL INFERENCE
stat 58.subject: Statistics
stat 58.description: Stochastic modes of convergence. Asymptotic theory of normed sums of random variables with applications to asymptotic normality of estimators. Methods for deriving limit distributions of nonlinear statistics. Asymptotic relative efficiencies. Asymptotic confidence regions and tests of hypotheses. Models of non-identically distributed or dependent random variables.

stat 59.name: THEORY OF PROBABILITY I
stat 59.subject: Statistics
stat 59.description: An introduction to measure theoretic probability and stochastic processes.Topics include foundations, independence, zero-one laws, laws of large numbers, convergence in distribution, characteristic functions, central limit theorems, random walks, conditional expectations. Familiarity with basic measure theory (e.g. MATH629 or 721) or concurrent registration in MATH721 is strongly recommended.
stat 59.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

stat 60.name: THEORY OF PROBABILITY II
stat 60.subject: Statistics
stat 60.description: Continuation of MATH/STAT733. Possible topics include martingales, weak convergence of measures, introduction to Brownian motion.
stat 60.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

stat 61.name: SURVIVAL ANALYSIS THEORY AND METHODS
stat 61.subject: Statistics
stat 61.description: Theory and practice of analytic methods for censored survival data, including nonparametric and parametric methods, the proportional hazards regression model, and a review of current topics in survival analysis.

stat 62.name: MULTIVARIATE ANALYSIS I
stat 62.subject: Statistics
stat 62.description: Multivariate normal distribution, estimation of mean and covariance matrix; Wishart distribution; distribution of partial and multiple correlation coefficients; Hotelling's T-squared, principal components.

stat 63.name: DECISION TREES FOR MULTIVARIATE ANALYSIS
stat 63.subject: Statistics
stat 63.description: Tree construction, including finding splits, tree-pruning and error estimation. Categorical predictor variables, missing or censored data, prior class-probabilities, and unequal misclassification costs. Selection bias. Comparison with other statistics and machine-learning methods. Extensions to piecewise linear and non-least squares regression models.

stat 64.name: STATISTICAL METHODS FOR MEDICAL IMAGE ANALYSIS
stat 64.subject: Statistics
stat 64.description: Introduce key statistical methods and concepts for analyzing various medical images. Analyze publicly available and student/instructor supplied imaging data using the most up-to-date methods and tools. Aimed at graduate student and researchers with strong quantitative background.

stat 65.name: STATISTICAL COMPUTING
stat 65.subject: Statistics
stat 65.description: The design of statistical software including special techniques for probability distributions, methods of simulation of random processes, numerical methods for linear models and multivariate analysis, and methods for nonlinear models.

stat 66.name: LINEAR RANDOMIZED ALGORITHMS FOR DATA SCIENCE
stat 66.subject: Statistics
stat 66.description: Introduce new algorithms that leverage randomization to address the scale, speed, and sensitivity needs of modern data science. Develop the mathematical foundations of such randomized algorithms. Criticize these algorithms through the lens of computational resource utilization. Implement these algorithms to address linear problems in data science.

stat 67.name: ADVANCED FINANCIAL STATISTICS
stat 67.subject: Statistics
stat 67.description: Statistical theory and methodology for modern financial data. Topics include financial stochastic models based on time series and stochastic calculus, modern statistical inference, and statistical learning for financial data as well as their applications to financial problems.

stat 68.name: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN I
stat 68.subject: Statistics
stat 68.description: Summary of matrix algebra required, theory of estimable functions, incomplete blocks, balanced incomplete block designs, partially balanced incomplete block designs.
stat 68.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

stat 69.name: NON PARAMETRIC STATISTICS
stat 69.subject: Statistics
stat 69.description: Statistical procedures valid under unrestrictive assumptions; sign test; confidence intervals; efficiency comparisons; signed rank procedures; Walsh sums; point estimators; two sample rank tests; zeros, ties, and other problems of discrete data; order statistics; Winsorized and truncated point estimators and connection with gross error models; permutation procedures; combinatorial problems, and computer applications.

stat 70.name: SAMPLE SURVEY THEORY AND METHOD
stat 70.subject: Statistics
stat 70.description: Simple random sampling; systematic sampling; probability sampling; stratified sampling; subsampling with units of equal and unequal size; double sampling; multi-stage and multi-phase sampling; ratio and regression estimates; model-based and model-assisted approaches; variance estimation; non-response.

stat 71.name: TOPICS IN THE THEORY OF PROBABILITY
stat 71.subject: Statistics
stat 71.description: Advanced topics in probability and stochastic processes.
stat 71.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

stat 72.name: EMPIRICAL PROCESSES AND SEMIPARAMETRIC INFERENCE
stat 72.subject: Statistics
stat 72.description: Empirical process methods in statistics; semiparametric models; stochastic convergence in metric spaces; Glivenko-Cantelli and Donsker theorems; entropy calculations; bootstrapped empirical processes; functional delta method; Z-estimators; M-estimators; rates of convergence; semiparametric efficiency; semiparametric estimating equations; nonparametric maximum likelihood.

stat 73.name: STATISTICAL MODEL BUILDING AND LEARNING
stat 73.subject: Statistics
stat 73.description: Theory of reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces in statistical model building; bounded linear functionals and representer theory; smoothing splines; ANOVA spines; degees of freedom for signal and the bias-variance tradeoff; Bayesian confidence intervals; model selection.

stat 74.name: NONPARAMETRIC STATISTICS AND MACHINE LEARNING METHODS
stat 74.subject: Statistics
stat 74.description: Statistical function estimation and classification; reproducing kernel machines, support vector machines; high dimensional model selection and estimation; Bayesian, empirical Bayesian interpretation of nonparametric learning methods; log density ANOVA and graphical models; tree ensemble methods including bagging, boosting, and random forest.

stat 75.name: THEORY AND APPLICATION OF REGRESSION AND ANALYSIS OF VARIANCE I
stat 75.subject: Statistics
stat 75.description: Theory and applications of the general linear model; graphical methods; simultaneous inference; regression diagnostics; analysis of variance of fixed, random and mixed effects models; ANCOVA: violations of assumptions.

stat 76.name: THEORY AND APPLICATION OF REGRESSION AND ANALYSIS OF VARIANCE II
stat 76.subject: Statistics
stat 76.description: Theory and applications of the general linear model; graphical methods; simultaneous inference; regression diagnostics; analysis of variance of fixed, random and mixed effects models; ANCOVA: violations of assumptions.

stat 77.name: ESTIMATION OF FUNCTIONS FROM DATA
stat 77.subject: Statistics
stat 77.description: Statistical and appoximation theoretic methods of estimating functions and values of functionals from experimental data; experimental design and data analysis problems that arise as problems in approximation theory; convergence theorems; ill-posed inverse problems; Banach and Hilbert space penalty functionals.

stat 78.name: THEORETICAL FOUNDATIONS OF MACHINE LEARNING
stat 78.subject: Statistics
stat 78.description: Advanced mathematical theory and methods of machine learning. Statistical learning theory, Vapnik-Chevronenkis Theory, model selection, high-dimensional models, nonparametric methods, probabilistic analysis, optimization, learning paradigms.

stat 79.name: STATISTICAL METHODS FOR MOLECULAR BIOLOGY
stat 79.subject: Statistics
stat 79.description: Develop statistical problems in gene mapping, high throughput -omics data analysis, phylogenetics and sequence analysis. Introduce ideas of key methods using published data. Statisticians learn statistical basis for research methodology. Collaboration among students and with biologists is encouraged through projects.

stat 80.name: TOPICS IN MATHEMATICAL DATA SCIENCE
stat 80.subject: Statistics
stat 80.description: Advanced topics in the mathematical foundations of data science
stat 80.requisite: Requisites: Graduate/professional standing or member of the Pre-Masters Mathematics (Visiting International) Program

stat 81.name: RESEARCH
stat 81.subject: Statistics
stat 81.description: Independent research and writing for graduate students under the supervision of a faculty member.

stat 82.name: SEMINAR
stat 82.subject: Statistics
stat 82.description: Special topics in statistics at the graduate level. Subject matter varies.
